Prepared Remarks:
OperatorGood morning and welcome to the Tenneco Incorporated First Quarter 2019 Earnings Conference Call. All participants will be in listen-only mode.(Operator Instructions) Please note this event is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Linae Golla, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead.Linae Golla -- Vice President, Investor RelationsThank you. This morning, we released our first quarter 2019 Earnings Result and related financial information. On today's call to discuss the results are Brian Kesseler and Roger Wood, Co-Chief Executive Officers; Jason Hollar, Chief Financial Officer and Ron Hundzinski, EVP, Finance. I'd also like to welcome to the call today, Rich Kwas, who was recently named as Vice President of Investor Relations for the new Tenneco division.Presentation corresponding to our prepared remarks, is available on the Investors section of our website. After our comments this morning, we will open the line for questions. Before we begin, please be aware that our discussion today will include information on non-GAAP financial measures, all of which are reconciled with GAAP measures in our press release attachments. Also note that all pro forma comparisons are measured at 2018 constant currency rates and include the Federal-Mogul acquisition in prior periods.The earnings release and attachments are available on our website. Additionally, some of our comments will include forward-looking statements. Please keep in mind that our actual results could differ materially from those projected in any of our forward-looking statements. Also note this quarter, we have revised our segment reporting into four segments and have recast historical pro forma results to match the new segmentation, which will help investors make the appropriate comparisons.Now, I will turn it over to Roger Wood, Co-CEO.Roger Wood -- Co-Chief Executive OfficerThank you Linae and good morning all. I'm pleased to be joined by my Co-CEO, Brian Kesseler. I will start-off with the highlights from the quarter. Ron and Jason will cover the reporting segments and the company's financial position and Brian will conclude with details and thoughts on our updated outlook. It was just over a year ago, April 10th in fact that we announced a strategic acquisition designed to transform Tenneco into two purpose-built industry leading independent businesses.Today, we're just as excited as we were a year ago. And just as committed to the creation of the two new companies, both for the opportunities that will bring to employees and the benefits that will be generated for our shareholders. You've seen in the press release that we've adjusted the timing on our expectations for the spin timing. We've made this adjustment to allow our businesses to setup processes, further improve margins, generate cash flow and strengthen our balance sheet. We're looking forward to spending mid 2020 or as soon as favorable conditions occur. Looking at the first quarter, we had some challenges, most of which we anticipated, a few which we did not. Even as global light vehicle production declined our organic growth continued to outpace industry production as we benefited from our diverse business profile. While aftermarket volumes were softer than we anticipated in the quarter, particularly in North America.Turning now to Q1 highlights on Page 4. In Q1 Tenneco generated $4.5 billion in revenue. On a pro forma basis this performance represented 1% organic growth year-over-year. New Tenneco grew revenues 3% organically year-over-year and DRiv revenues declined 3%. As you can see on the slide light vehicle revenues increased 1% year-over-year and outperform global light vehicle production by 800 bps. CTOH increased 7% and aftermarket declined 8% on an organic basis.Currency was a 5% headwind. EBITDA margin was 8.7%, down 150 basis points year-over-year. We anticipated, much of the China volume decline but aftermarket volumes in North America were impacted by overall market softness more than we expected. In addition, we also experienced some operating inefficiencies and unanticipated non-recurring costs. Jason and Ron will discuss the margin results and action plans in more detail later in the presentation.Adjusted EPS was $0.52 versus $1.62 last year. Please note that the $1.62 represents legacy Tenneco and is not a pro forma comparison. The decline was influenced by higher depreciation and amortization, interest expense and share count all related to the acquisition of Federal-Mogul which was completed on October 1, 2018.During the quarter, we continued to demonstrate a strong focus on technology, innovation and improving our business for the future. First let me congratulate the teams from new Tenneco who received two pace awards for innovative new products recently launched into serial production. We also continue to look for the right opportunities to strengthen the portfolio for both divisions as we did for DRiv this quarter when we closed the Ohlins acquisition and sold the Wiper business. As mentioned on prior calls with investors we are operating as two stand-alone businesses.As such, we want to offer as much transparency to investors as we work toward the separation. The following slides will discuss each division's performance and relevant segments.So please turn to Page 5. In Q1, new Tenneco posted nearly $2.3 billion of revenue, flat year-over-year on a constant currency and pro forma basis. New Tenneco outperformed global light vehicle production and experienced good growth withing the CTOH business. On the lower left, you can see FX cost most of the year-over-year decline in the division's revenues. EBITDA declined 17% year-over-year to $236 million and margin was 10.5%, down from 12.1% in the year ago period. On lower right, weaker operating performance caused most of the year-over-year decline. Also, we incurred incremental corporate costs as we build the infrastructure to run the business, as a stand-alone public company. I'll now turn it over to Ron for discussion of new Tenneco and its segments. Ron?Ron Hundzinski -- Executive Vice President, FinanceThank you, Roger, and good morning everyone. Roger has just gone over the total new Tenneco. Now, I'll provide more details on performance and our Clean Air and Powertrain segments. On Page 6, we show Clean Air's performance. Value added revenues increased 2% year-over-year on a constant currency basis. We saw good outperformance in light vehicle and strong CTOH growth. On the lower left, you see segment revenues benefited from positive volume mix and price, well, which was more than offset by FX.Adjusted EBITDA was $140 million down 13% year-over-year, adjusted EBITDA margin was 13.1% compared to 14.5% in the prior year period. When you build down the performance in Q1, we were $14 million lower in adjusted EBITDA on an $18 million increase in sales. This does exclude the impact of currency. Normally, we would expect positive adjusted EBITDA contribution year-over-year on higher sales. The Adjusted EBITDA under performance was impacted by a $5 million supplier bankruptcy and $3 million related to engineering timing recovery.These two items should not repeat in Q2. Additional performance headwinds included labor inefficiencies in Europe, steel costs and lower sales in China, which have higher margins. Now on Page 7, we show Powertrain segment performance. Value added revenues were $1.18 billion representing a negative 2% decrease year-over-year. Light vehicle revenues slightly outperformed the global market and CTOH revenue growth was healthy. Adjusted EBITDA was $116 million, down 70% year-over-year. Adjusted EBITDA margin was 9.9%, down approximately 120 basis points from the 11.1% rate in the year ago period. Excluding the impact of currency, we experienced a decrease in adjusted EBITDA of $16 million and a decrease in sales of $27 million. About $6 million of the EBITDA drop was related to unfavorable mix from diesel pistons to gasoline, our diesel pistons business is more profitable than our petrol pistons and the shift away from light vehicle diesels in Europe weighed on our margins. We expect this dynamic to continue for the next couple of quarters at a moderating pace. Another $6 million was caused by the year-over-year decline in China sales, which carry higher margins relative to other geographic areas we serve. We've commenced incremental restructuring actions in the quarter to reduce overhead and infrastructure costs and anticipate these benefits to be realized in the second half of the year.Now if we look at the DRiV business and it's ride performance motor parts segment results, I'll turn the call over to Jason.Jason Hollar -- Executive Vice President, Chief Financial OfficerThanks, Ron. On Page 8, you'll find the combined overview of revenue and adjusted EBITDA for DRiV's two reporting segments. Total revenue for DRiV was down 3% in the quarter and adjusted EBITDA was also lower versus last year, mainly due to lower aftermarket sales in North America and lower year-over-year light vehicle production volumes in China. Our fundamental growth drivers remain strong and we remain focused on satisfying our customer's needs.Some of the highlights in the quarter include, we recaptured business with two North America aftermarket buying groups previously lost due to perceived channel conflict. The motor parts team was recognized as Vendor of the Year by Parts Warehouse. For the third time in the past four years, our Clevite NVH Performance Materials Group was named the Supplier of the Year by General Motors. And the OE Ride Performance team won two new incremental business awards for our CVSA2 Kinetic advanced suspension technology in Europe. One on the new electric vehicle and another on a luxury sports group.Turning the baseline for a closer look at the motor parts segment. Year-over-year revenue and adjusted EBITDA are both lower versus last year. The charts on the right side, show a lot from Q1 2018 pro forma to Q1 2019 actuals and you can see volume and mix are the main drivers of both the revenue and earnings results. Overall market weakness with lower out the door sales in North America impacted results and in Europe, some key customers continue to adjust inventory following recent acquisitions. The Asia Pacific region delivered a good quarter with growth in both China and India. These volume and mix headwinds were partially offset by synergies and other operating performance improvements.Ride performance segment results on Page 10. Revenue in the first quarter was up 2% with growth in light vehicle as well as commercial truck applications. Revenue in North America was up year-over-year mainly on higher NVH Performance Materials content of commercial trucks, light vehicle and the growing number of battery electric vehicle platforms. In addition, revenues from our recently completed acquisition of Ohlins have been included, partially offset by the vehicle business that was sold in March 1st. DRiV Performance, adjusted EBITDA was $31 million and value-added adjusted EBITDA margin was 4.2%. Margin performance was primarily impacted by operational inefficiencies related to our manufacturing footprint actions under way in North America and China. The remaining manufacturing processes for the China relocation will be completed in the second quarter with efficiencies ramping up through the third quarter. An update of our Q1 debt and cash position is on Page 11. The table on the left side of the page shows our net debt position and pro forma net leverage ratio at the end of the first quarter compared to year-end 2018. During the first quarter, interest expense was $81 million and that includes the discount on factored receivables, which is now classified as interest expense in this and prior periods.In terms of our debt profile, there are no significant near-term maturities. We suffer scheduled amortization of term loans under the senior credit facility. Our long-term debt principal payments are not payable until 2022 and later. The leverage ratio was partially impacted by the normal seasonality of cash flow and at then in the first quarter, the company had $1.7 billion of liquidity available. It is not on the Slide, but I would like to point out that the first quarter adjusted effective tax rate of 32% was impacted by our geographic mix of income in the quarter. However, our full year tax rate guidance remained at 28% to 30%.With that, I'll turn the call over to Brian.Brian Kesseler -- Co-Chief Executive OfficerThank you, Jason. Before, I go through the outlook, let me take a minute to thank the Tenneco team members around the world for all they do every day to take care of our customers and make our Company successful. Across Tenneco, we have a heightened focus on lowering our fixed cost base and continuing to simplify each of our businesses by eliminating waste and non-value added complexity. Most of all, in everything we do, we do things the right way with no shortcuts and again, my thanks to the team.The updated enterprise outlook is on Page 12. Starting with the second quarter, we expect revenue in the range of $4.45 billion to $4.55 billion with pro forma revenue about flat on a sequential basis at the midpoint of that range. In the second quarter, we expect DRiv revenues to be up 4% to 5% sequentially with aftermarket revenues returning to expected levels. We anticipate new Tenneco business to be down 1% to 2% sequentially, driven mainly by lower light vehicle production in Europe. In the second quarter, we expect improved profitability in both businesses with adjusted EBITDA in a range of $375 million to $395 million, which is nearly a 20% improvement sequentially but, the aftermarket revenues returning to expected levels and the ramping of synergies and other initiatives.For the full year, we are revising our revenue outlook slightly, which we now expect to be in a range of $17.7 million to $18.1 billion, or growth of 3% year-over-year, in part due to lower European light vehicle production and the inclusion of a modest decline in commercial vehicle markets year-over-year. We expect outpace industry light vehicle production by 6%. We expect value added adjusted EBITDA for the full year to be in the range of $1.5 billion to $1.62 billion or between 10% and 10.6%. The outlook, specifically for DRiV is on Page 13.For the second quarter, we expect sequential revenue growth of 4% to 5% and a better aftermarket performance. We also expect sequential margin improvement of approximately 200 basis points higher than last year's Q1 to Q2 improvement of 110 basis points. Margin growth will come from higher revenues, the benefit of synergy actions and other manufacturing improvements in the second quarter. For the full year, we anticipate revenues to be about flat year-over-year.Our ROE ride Performance business is expected to be about flat, continuing to outpace light vehicle industry production and we expect the motor parts business to be up slightly year-over-year as we begin to lap the loss business in the second half of last year. We anticipate full year adjusted EBITDA margin to be about flat versus last year with the runway for further improvement in 2020. By Q4 2019 we are confident that we will achieve a 75% run rate for earnings synergies related to the transaction and expect actions to be phased in throughout the year.As Jason mentioned the China Ride Performance production relocation will be finalized in Q2 and volumes are expected to stabilize and ramp up in Q3. We expect CapEx to be in the range of $250 million and $275 million for the year. This is heavier than normal, driven by the investment in Ride Performance as we implement the North American footprint consolidation, expand our capacity in Eastern Europe and finalize the plant relocation in China.Now, I'll turn it back to Roger for the New Tenneco outlook.Roger Wood -- Co-Chief Executive OfficerThank you, Brian. Please turn to Page 14. For Q2, we estimate New Tenneco's value added revenue will decline 1% to 2% versus Q1, largely due to incremental pressure on light vehicle production in Europe relative to the start of the year and more subdued growth in our CTOH revenues related to market adjustments. We believe Clean Air growth will exceed Powertrain. We estimate New Tenneco segment margin will increase approximately a 100 basis points sequentially at the midpoint from the Q1 to Q2 to around 11.5%. The impact from the supplier bankruptcy should page and commercial activities are expected to gain momentum. Incremental productivity actions and synergy contribution also should yield benefits sequentially speaking. For the full year, we reduced our constant currency value added revenue growth estimate to 3% to 4% from 6% to 7%. On a dollar basis, we estimate total revenues to be $11.43 billion to $11.73 billion. Lower European light vehicle production and a modest negative adjustment to our global commercial vehicle production forecast are the primary changes versus our initial revenue growth guidance. On the margin front, we expect a 30 basis point to 50 basis point year-over-year decrease into value added adjusted EBITDA margin relative to our newly recasted 2018 figures. Our range is 11.7% to 12.2%.We expect CapEx for the year in the range of $480 million to $495 million. Please turn to Page 15. We anticipate our year-end 2019 leverage ratio to be approximately 3.3 times, using the midpoint of our new EBITDA guidance. Our prior guidance was 3.0 times. EBITDA reduction is the primary reason for the change in the outlook. We are working diligently to improve margin and cash flow over the balance of the year. We have decided to shift our anticipated spend timing to mid 2020. We believe the extra time will allow us to further improve margins, cash flow conversion, strengthen our balance sheet and complete the spend as soon as favorable conditions emerge. Brian, did you have any thoughts before we open the call up to questions?Brian Kesseler -- Co-Chief Executive OfficerYes. Thanks, Roger. As you mentioned in the beginning, it was just over a year ago, we announced this combination and like you, I'm just as enthusiastic, now, as I was then. Since, we closed the deal and began working on combining these great businesses, we've seeing a number of challenges, we didn't expect. Everything from lower light vehicle volumes in China, a temporary drop over the last couple of quarters and the aftermarket revenue and the trade and tariff issues that the entire industry has been wrestling with.With a couple of tough quarters behind us, we've worked through some challenges and from an operational standpoint, we have our arms around the business. For the first time, we have both leadership teams in place and operating as independent businesses as we will after the separation. The teams are highly engaged in driving results and we expect continued quarter-after-quarter margin improvements. We're seeing the benefits of synergies starting to ramp and other operational improvements focused on growing our top line and increasing our profitability. Continuing to optimize our portfolio with strategic acquisitions and divestitures that will help set each business up for success and the new Tenneco is uniquely positioned as a full system partner to the OEMs fuel economy and emissions solutions from the cylinder of the tail pipe and for DRiv being the industry leader in advanced OE suspension technology with the largest global multi-line, multi-brand aftermarket products in the world. There were some growing pains combining these two businesses. But like the last couple of quarters that are behind us, we are moving forward with confidence, and speed. We believe both new companies have an exciting future, and we look forward to sharing our progress with you next quarter. Thank you for your continued interest in Tenneco and for joining us this morning.With that, we can open the lines for questions.

Questions and Answers:OperatorWe will now begin the question-and-answer session. (Operator Instructions) Our first question comes from Colin Langan with UBS. Please go ahead.Unidentified ParticipantHey guys, this is (ph) Tim Vladimir offline for Colin. Good morning.Roger Wood -- Co-Chief Executive OfficerGood morning.Unidentified ParticipantWith the lower fiscal year margin guidance I was wondering if you could walk us through how we should be thinking about the margin cadence throughout the year? The Q2 guide appears to be about the low end of guidance so it suggests pretty meaningful improvement in 2H, just wondering what the big drivers would be there.Brian Kesseler -- Co-Chief Executive OfficerYeah, probably the best way to think about that is as the synergies start to ramp in, you can see a good improvement in Q1 to Q2. The second half of the year than in the balance out to that overall flat level of outlook, you should expect to see meaningful improvement to be able to reach that in that -- it needs the two quarters, so the back half of the year.Unidentified ParticipantOkay. And then, could you give us some color on the cash plan for the quarter, is it going to come in about where you guys had expected and how should we be thinking about that going forward as well?Brian Kesseler -- Co-Chief Executive OfficerWhat I'd say about that is, when you look at both businesses the legacy of both businesses, both have a relatively similar type of seasonality element. So similar to all our other peers and the first quarter tends to be a lower cash quarter than than the other quarters. And so within that, it's fairly consistent with what you'd expect on historical basis.Unidentified ParticipantGot it, OK. Thanks for taking our question.Roger Wood -- Co-Chief Executive OfficerThanks.OperatorThe next question comes from Armintas Sinkevicius with Morgan Stanley. Please go ahead.Armintas Sinkevicius -- Morgan Stanley -- AnalystGood morning. Thank you for taking the question.Roger Wood -- Co-Chief Executive OfficerGood morning.Armintas Sinkevicius -- Morgan Stanley -- AnalystJust wanted to understand when we received the guidance for 2019 it was in the middle of March, presumably, there is visibility on what the first quarter was looking like. So what -- why are we getting this now versus last quarter?Brian Kesseler -- Co-Chief Executive OfficerYes, the one thing that changed, a bit stronger than we thought or a bit weaker than we thought was North America aftermarket. If you looked at the overall market and you looked at the outer door sales. January was about where we expected it to be, the back end of February, started to see some slip from a year-over-year basis and if you listen to most of our customers, March was a tough month. And so, as we were talking near the middle of the quarter, it was really aftermarket and if you look at the bridge as you can see the impact that has on our overall earnings.Light vehicle industry did moved down a little bit further than we expected. There was some downtime taken that we didn't anticipate and so, catching us a little bit short with that dramatic move or those bigger moves. Our ability to flex out really wasn't there. We've made those flexes, we've aligned to that level of capacity and ideally as these -- as these revenues come back, we'll chase them up.Armintas Sinkevicius -- Morgan Stanley -- AnalystOkay. And I was surprised to hear that the growing pains combining the businesses, it seems like a pretty sort of straightforward combination where the Federal-Mogul pieces of the business complemented yours pretty well and outside of the hiccups with how to -- how and what to expense that delayed the 10-K, what growing pains are you referring to?Brian Kesseler -- Co-Chief Executive OfficerWell, a little bit. I would where most of the change happened was more on the DRiv side as we kind of realign the OE businesses together and realign the aftermarket businesses. From an operational perspective, the ability to run the operations really wasn't that impacted. It was more around getting the systems set up and aligned, so that we can see the business in a common way. I wouldn't choke up a lot of that to the operational performance, but it did have some influence. But the revenue drop was really the bigger issue -- the biggest issue here in what we had to react to.Armintas Sinkevicius -- Morgan Stanley -- AnalystOkay. And then what drove you to push out the spin timing?Roger Wood -- Co-Chief Executive OfficerI think -- I think the, as we said in the call, that it gives us a little bit of an opportunity as Brian had mentioned to make sure that we are grounded and where we're going forward, get in the sequence that we've got outlined for the rest of the year and we have confidence in the go forward as Brian said the last couple of quarters haven't been real good ,but we have a lot of confidence now that we've got our arms around it. That's behind us and we're moving forward in a positive way and we just think it gives us a better opportunity to straighten up the balance sheet a little bit, get our operating efficiencies in line, get some performance behind us and do it in a fashion that gives us the confidence at the spin date, the things are where we need them to be.Armintas Sinkevicius -- Morgan Stanley -- AnalystGot it. Much appreciated.OperatorThe next question comes from James Picariello with KeyBanc. Please go ahead.James Picariello -- KeyBanc -- AnalystGood morning guys. Just focusing on the ride performance, the new ride performance segment. Can we kind of parse out what, how the legacy Tenneco Ride Performance business performed and relative to the OE portion for motor parts?Brian Kesseler -- Co-Chief Executive OfficerSo I think most of the pressure we saw on the year-over-year related to the legacy Ride Performance. Both businesses, both product lines, both the breakeven and the ride control were influenced by the China volumes for sure on a year-over-year basis. Lot of that wasn't a surprise, but -- and we also knew that we are going to have some inefficiencies in the year for the footprint moves we have going on in North America and the relocation of China.So as we look at what surprised us if anything on the ride performance side, not much, I mean we knew these inefficiencies were going to be there. You can also see that in our guidance. We stayed on our guidance for margins and so moving through that we are not -- we'll lap some of this aftermarket North America stuff. We are starting to see good out the door comps here in April and the first part of May. Quarter-to-quarter that's what's giving us the confidence in our Q2 outlook.James Picariello -- KeyBanc -- AnalystOkay. And did you, -- have you quantified the China inefficiencies regarding the planned move?Brian Kesseler -- Co-Chief Executive OfficerNo, we haven't. It's -- There is a mix in there, but the volume down and then the plant move. So it'll be kind of hard to split those out. They're all through one location and through the supply chain. So it's really a combination of both of those.James Picariello -- KeyBanc -- AnalystGot it. And just to go back to the question on delaying the spin here, is it -- was it or is it an issue tied to getting the financing completed for both businesses, and just wondering if that played any role and then you just broadly, what do you want to see over the next 12 months to get you more comfortable with the drive spin, actually happening then? I mean, is it -- ride performances margins stabilizing, waiting for a better macro environment, maybe several things there? Just curious, your overall decision.Brian Kesseler -- Co-Chief Executive OfficerI kind of echo what Roger was saying, we want to get the market show that the margins are getting to where we expect them to be, make sure that we lock those in and stabilize those and give our stakeholders the confidence that we're on the upward trajectory that we expect to be, give us a little bit more time to make sure the systems are combined and separated. So from an operational perspective that definitely derisk there and that's about the balance sheet. Let's get the balance sheet where we expect it to be and then have the right financing in place. And again, the macro environment has got to be right to your point, I mean, we're not going to spin just a spin but when all the conditions are where we expect them to be in both businesses are in the place to be successful coming out of the separation, that's when we'll pull the trigger.James Picariello -- KeyBanc -- AnalystSo did you -- I mean, I assume that you tested the financing market was that something that you didn't -- the reception was not as healthy enough to move forward, was that -- did that plan?Jason Hollar -- Executive Vice President, Chief Financial OfficerNo, not at all. I would say that, we had really great reception with all the prospective channels for financing that we looked at and it's a good environment still for that and it's entirely based upon what Brian or Roger laid out.James Picariello -- KeyBanc -- AnalystThanks guys.OperatorThe next question comes from David Tamberrino with Goldman Sachs. Please go ahead.David Tamberrino -- Goldman Sachs -- AnalystYes, good morning. I Just want to understand the aftermarket side a little bit better and kind of the weakness that you've seen or we're seeing in February into March. One, has that continued into April and early May, you're seeing signs of some positivity? And then just what's driven the weak demand, is there any pull forward of stocking, has there been inventory destocking in the channel? Is that over? if not how much longer do you think you could really last, just trying to get a better sense of what you're seeing and what's transpired because there's a lot of noise in the market right now from the camp of different companies?Brian Kesseler -- Co-Chief Executive OfficerYes, let me, I'll give you may be two parts of that answer, David. The overall market, I mean, every customer that we see out the door and every customer in the traditional channel and all the retail channels in Q1. Especially in the back half of Q1, we saw high single digit out of the door comps go down, pretty dramatically on our categories. There were a couple of categories that in cold snaps so better than others, but those aren't ours. We have seen in April, low single-digit comps come back positive. We see that continuing in demand out the door. So, I do think there was a bit of a lag in there. I was raised in the aftermarket never to talk about weather but, similarly there seems -- there is some effect there. So, that would be from a macro perspective, the impact. And like I said in the back half of Q1, April and the early returns in May we're seeing across the Board, their market lifts in the low-single digits increase and that's why we're confident in the outlook that we've given you. As you -- anybody who is following the aftermarket, there is one of our largest customers that is going through an inventory realignment to be more favorably comps to their peer group. And so, as we work through that with our customer there's going to be some puts and takes so that probably through the balance of the year. But that's anticipated in the outlook that we've given.David Tamberrino -- Goldman Sachs -- AnalystOkay. And then, I understand the top line covenants and what you're seeing at least in the near-term trends. But from a margin standpoint, I mean, what is your covenants level or in overall as to how much of a handle you have on the issues that have transpired and you've been facing and that you've correctly identified them and can address them in due course?Brian Kesseler -- Co-Chief Executive OfficerYes, I'll speak for the drives and then hand it over to Roger. From a margin perspective, we are wrestling through last year and a little bit the year before. The margin hits that we had on steel economics, we've rustled those to the ground, got the right agreements in place and dialog going with our customers.And operationally, we're coming to the end of the China relocation, finally, at the end of this quarter. We're beginning to then -- early next year we'll start to see the benefits of our North American footprint, but from an overall perspective within the guidance and outlook that we're given I'm confident with where we're at.Roger Wood -- Co-Chief Executive OfficerYeah. And from the Powertrain side of the business I equally as I am confident there, David. The issues that we've experienced in both sides of the business that are part of our portfolio over here. We have a good handle on those. One of them is behind us, we believe the supplier bankruptcy that took a bit of time and a lot of money to get us through it without interruptions to our customer base. That was a first quarter issue and that's behind us now and over. We do have some performance areas of the business that we know we've got to improve upon. Europe is one of them. That's kind of sticks out for us and we know what actions they're taking over in Europe to accomplish that.But we've got to continue to focus on that. We know what's going to be done and we know the actions that we have in place to do that. As Brian said material economics as well is something that we continue to work on with our customers. Tariffs and material economics are an issue that quite frankly everybody in the value chain is going to have to pay a little bit of -- and all of it. It can't be resting in any one place in the supply chain. So we will continue to work on those with our customers have good receptivity actually with our customers on that front to make sure that we're all sharing and what we have to share in there. So again, all the actions are in place. We're confident in it and we got a sequential improvement -- significant sequential improvement, coming-off of the first quarter into the second quarter and through the rest of the year and subject to market fluctuations that while we can't control the top line, we can focus and make sure that we're holding the bottom line, if it's a decline in the top line will hold the bottom line under detrimental basis and if we are fortunate enough to see a sales increase to make sure that we gain the income on the upside.David Tamberrino -- Goldman Sachs -- AnalystOkay. And just the last one from me, is I think about where you're going to end the year pro forma from a leverage perspective, is there any updated thinking as to how you would, just break down what you think the different businesses Post-spin could look like from a leverage perspective just given a little bit of a back-tracking from where I think you originally was supposed to retargeting?Brian Kesseler -- Co-Chief Executive OfficerYes. I think what -- Here's the way it would probably -- it's going to continue to shake out. When we get to the spin decision and we get to the financing, our Board and is going to make the right call on making sure it's business is set up for success in the short, medium and long-term. So, probably a little early, too early to call.
